definition: Li Zicheng (1605-1645), leader of peasant rebellion at the end of the Ming Dynasty
plum
surname Li
self/oneself/from/since/naturally/surely
surname Cheng
to succeed/to finish/to complete/to accomplish/to become/to turn into/to be all right/OK!/one tenth

sentences.english: After the besiege of Beijing, Li Zicheng became dilapidated.
sentences.chinese: 後圍攻北京，李自成變得破舊。

sentences.english: Especially, Li Tzu-cheng may be the next emperor of China.
sentences.chinese: 尤其李自成還可能是下一個中國皇帝呢。

sentences.english: Li Zicheng was afraid with both of the other two.
sentences.chinese: 李自成恐怕與雙方的其他兩個。

sentences.english: Recently, I read a book about Li Zicheng.
sentences.chinese: 最近，我看了一本書李自成。

sentences.english: Gao's generals together nominated Li Zicheng to be King of Chuang.
sentences.chinese: 高的將領一起提名李自成被國王闖。

sentences.english: Li Zicheng was a poor peasant of Mizhi County, Shaanxi Province.
sentences.chinese: 李自成是一個貧苦農民的米脂縣陝西省。

definition: Wu Sangui (1612-1678), Chinese general who let the Manchus into China and helped them establish the Qing Dynasty, later leading a revolt against Qing in an effort to start his own dynasty
Zhang Xianzhong (1606-1647), leader of a late-Ming peasant revolt
Chongzhen, reign name of last Ming emperor (1628-1644)
Chuangwang or Roaming King, adopted name of late Ming peasant rebel leader Li Zicheng 李自成 (1605-1645)
the Qing army

Hong Taiji (1592-1643), eighth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, reigned 1626-1636 as Second Khan of Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金, then founded the Qing dynasty 大清 and reigned 1636-1643 as Emperor/posthumous name 清太宗
Dorgon (1612-1651), fourteenth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, successful general, instrumental in Manchu conquest of China, ruled China as regent 1644-1650 for his nephew Emperor Shunzhi 順治帝
Zhu Di, personal name of third Ming Emperor Yongle 永樂|永乐[Yong3 le4]
Zhu Yuanzhang, personal name of first Ming dynasty emperor Hongwu 洪武[Hong2 wu3]
Later Jin dynasty (from 1616-)/Manchu Khanate or kingdom that took over as Qing dynasty in 1644
Nurhaci (1559-1626), founder and first Khan of the Manchu Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金 (from 1616)
Manchurian Qing (refers to the Qing dynasty, esp. at its decline, or as an anti-Qing slogan)
Hong Xiuquan or Hung Hsiu-ch'üan (1814-1864), leader of the Taiping rebellion or Taiping Heavenly Kingdom
reign name of second Ming emperor, reigned 1398-1402, deposed in 1402
Taiping Heavenly Kingdom (1851-1864)
reign name of second Qing emperor (1644-1662)
